headline: Department of Justice allows Ohio to delay sending military, overseas primary ballots
author: Haley BeMiller
sentences: Ohio reached an agreement with the federal government on Friday to delay sending ballots to military and overseas voters, giving election officials more time to finalize them as a May 3rd primary hangs in the balance.

Haley BeMiller is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated news organizations across Ohio.
LaRose told DeWine and lawmakers on Thursday that it's impossible to put legislative races on the May 3rd ballot unless a federal court allows Ohio to use previously rejected maps.
LaRose previously said holding two primaries could cost taxpayers an extra $20 million to $25 million, and his office already received $9.2 million to help prepare for May.
"(The department) made clear that Ohio’s accommodations will be adequate to make sure every overseas Ohioan who wants to cast a ballot will be able to do so," LaRose said.
House Democrats argued the changes will disenfranchise military voters, but Secretary of State Frank LaRose said rushed mail will ensure they have enough time to vote.

Overseas voters will have 10 extra days after the election to return their ballots, as long as they're mailed by election day.
